div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,504] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE. SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundaus, Tuesdays, and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary night trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
ENGLAND AND RUSSIA
div.p: The English daily Newspaper, Establish 1839.
Editior and Manager - - R. SHELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF
MONDAY, May 28, 1906.

Tbs Berlin correspondent of the' Standard,' writing on the subject of an Anglo-Russian Agreement, says that it is stated, with a great show of sincerity, in official circles there, that the German Government would warmly wel- come an Anglo-Russian agreement, which should remove existing differences between the two Powers.

It is declared that Germany, as a Power which is pledged to a policy of peace, must regard favourably the conclusion of each an agreement, which, by removing possible causes of friction between two great countries like . Great Britain and Russia, would promote the maintenance of the peace of the world. Just as Germany and every other civilised Power would suffer by an Anglo-Russian conflict, so, it is declared, Germany and other countries will benefit from a definite settlement of Anglo-Russian a controversies. It should be borne in mind, in reading this exposition of German official opinion, that the German Go- vernment greeted the Anglo-French Agreement of 1904 with equal amiability, and that grave objections to the terms of the compact between Great Britain and France regarding Morocco were subsequently raised when the general international situation gave Germany a favour- able opportunity of so doing.

Although Germans see no menace to them- selves in a settlement of the differences be- tween England and Russia in Asia, they, nevertheless, regard an Anglo Russian entente as a development which may contain future dangers for them. No official assurances can conceal the fact that Germans regard the inti- mate relations now existing between Great Britain and France and Great Britain and Russia, supplemented, as they are, by the Anglo-Japanese agreement, and the extreme'y friendly relations between England on the one side, and Italy, Spain and Portugal on the other, as combinations which contain the pos- sibility of menace to Germany's own position. The assurances that the AngloRussian agree- ment, as outlined in the“Standard,"are viewed with approval by Germany, may be accepted as genuine, with the reservation that respon- sible Germans regard any AngloRussian en- tente with suspicion, owing to the possibility that it may assume an anti-German tendency at some future time.

Regarding the details of the possible Anglo- Russian agreement, Germany is principally erected in the provisions concerning Persia and the Baghdad Railway. The policy of Germany in regard to the future of Persia is that absolute equality of commercial opportu- nity must be upheld there, as in all other entries. The German Government would certainly object to the conclusion of an agree- ment between any other Powers which might injuriously affect Germany's legitimate com- mercial interests in Persia.

It is assumed, however, in Berlin that the policy of Germany regarding the maintenance the "open door" is so well known in England d Russia that the new agreement will not contain anything which could excite opposi- te in this respect. It may be stated with great emphasis that the suggestion that the eastern section of the Baghdad Railway from Baghdad to the Persian Gulf should be placed under British control is regarded in Berlin as absolutely unacceptable. On the other hand there is no fundamental objection to the pro- posal that this section might be internation- alised. It will be remembered that attempts were previously made to obtain financial sup- port in England for this railway, and that French capital is invested in the scheme. It pointed out, however, that the Deutsche ink obtained the right to construct tho rail- way to the Persian Gulf, and that neither Great Britain nor Russia can tamper with this concession, which the bank in question obtained from the Imperial Ottoman Govern- ment.

If any attempt were made to tamper with the rights of the Deutsche Bank Germany would certainly protect the interests of this great financial institution, just as the British govermnent would safeguard the rights of any British bank in similar circumstances. It is pointed out that if Great Britain and Russia now desire to have a share in the manage- ment of any part of the Baghdad Railway they must initiate negotiations with the Deutsche Bank, which alone possesses the right to accept or reject any proposals made on this subject.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Police School.
In the early part of 1907 and inspector of the Ministry of the Interior will be appointed to direct the Police School at Cairo.
El-Hussein Mouled.
The Ministry of the Interior has authorised the holding of the Mouled of El-Hussein in Cairo, next month, for a period of 10 days, instead of 24.
The Fleet.
It was expected that the whole of the Mediterranean fleet would have returned to Malta by to-day. The fleet will leave again early in June.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal into egypt from January 1 to the 24th inst. amounted to 518,635 tons, as compared with 338,178 tons during the corresponding period last year.
Land Sale.
Count Menander Ziziniz has sold to M. Issac Aghion and Abdul Razak el-Far and abadieh of six hundred and sixty-six fedduas at Zargoum, Behera, for L.E. 40,000.
New Hotel Company.
Some Greek capitalists resident in Egypt are creditied f=with the intention of forming a company for the establishment of high-class hotels in Athens and other Greek towns.
The Plague.

During the lass week 13 cases of plague were reported, two of which occured at Port Said, 9 at Samalout, and one each in Minieh and Ghirgeh provinces. The total number of cases reported to dat this year is 329.
Chauffeurs at Cario.

An agitation is afoot at Cario in favour of the Government making some regulations to prevent inexperienced persons being allowed to act as chauffeurs, and the attention of the Auto- mobile Club has been drawn to the question.
New Mexican Consul-General.

M. George Violara, the well-known merchant, recieved a telegram from the President of the Mexican Republic yesturday appointing him Mexican Consul-General at Alexandria in suc- cession to the late Son Antonio de Beneducci.
Egyptian State Domain Bonds.

The numbers are publiched of drawn bonds of the Egyptian State Domain, amounting to £207,800, to be paid off on June 1st. The drawing consits of all the bonds not pre- voiusly cancelled by the operation of the sink- ing fund.
Popular University.

M.R.G. Canivet lectures at the University this evening on "Les facteurs de l'Evolution: La lutte pour la vie et son ro'e social," being the fifth of a series of lectures on scientific, social, and literary evolution. The lecture will commence at 9.15 p.m. and entrance is free.
Egypt and Europe.

Mr. H. Margosches has obtained a contract from the Alexandria Municipality for the supply of 30,000 enamel plaques. It is satisfactory to note that contracts such as this are now execut- ed in the country, whereas they were formerly sent to Europe. Little as it is in itself, it is an undoubted sign that progress is being made in the country's industries.
Islam in Sudan.

A few months ago a subscription was started by the Moslem Press for the purpose of raising funds to send a she kh to the Southern Sudan to convert the heathen there to Islam. A sheikh offered to understake the work if £400 were forthcoming. A few days ago Dr. Mah- moud Bey Lebib Moharrem, of Alexandria, sent a cheque of £200 to "Al Moayad" for the work and promised to give a similar amount every year.
Sir Elwin Palmer's Will.

Sir Elwin Mitford Palmer, of Cairo, Governor of the NAtional Bank of Egypt, and formerly Financial Adviser to the Khedive, who died on January 28, gave to his wife Dame Mary Augusta Lynch Palmer £2,000, the furniture and household effects, and the income from one moiety of the residue of his property. Subject thereto the whole of his estate, the value whereof is £9,406 16s. 6d. gross and £9,467 11s. 4d. net, is to be divided among his children.

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: MARKED RISE OF BLUE NILE.

The latest records show a rapid and gratify- ing rise on the Blue Nile at Rosaires, where the levels rose from 11m. 47cm. to 12m. 80cm. in two days, a total of 1m. 33cm. The flood should reach Khartoum early in July, and there is every reason, after this start, to hope for a very good Nile.

It is regrettable that returns from Dueim are not sent up to Cairo at shorter intervals. The station is a good point for the observation of the White Nile, and though the Abyssinian river is the most important for the cultivator, the White Nile records are always of con- siderable value.

div.head: THE NILE EXPEDITION
div.p: News has just been recieved from Major Powell Cotton's ecpedition, which left England 18 months ago on a journey from the Nile to the Zambesi. At the end of March the explorer and his wife were at Makalo, Congo Free State, in the heart of the Ituri rubber district, and one of the cheif haunts of the okapi, where the expedition proposed to remain for a month or so in a final endevour to secure specimens. The progress of the expedition has created much interest among the pygmy and other forest tribes, Mrs. Powell Cotton being the first European women to penetrate the Ituri basin, and the camp has been thronged daily with natives curious to see the "white women with the long hair." The explorers were in good health and were receiving every assistance from the authorities.

div.head: REDUCTION IN POSTAGE TO ITALY
div.p: From an official communication received from the General Post Office, it appears that an agreement concerning the reduction of postage on letters exchanged between Egypt and Italy has been signed at Rome, and will come into force on the 1st July next. The exact details are not yet to hand.

div.head: RAILWAYS IN UPPER EGYPT
div.p: A CHAPTER OF ACCINDENTS

Out Luxer Correspondent writes: - Quite a chapter of accidents happened on the Luxor- Assouan Railway las Monday. The express train from Assouan which ought to arrive here at 4.40 p.m. got her axle-box broken at Komombo and the engine that went to her assistance from Assouan broke down on the way, with her excentrics, and another had to be sent from here, which brought in the train at midnight.

The mixed train, which left here at 5.15 a.m.m had to stop owing to her boiler leaking, while the express that left here at 10.25 a.m. for Assouan burst one of its boiler tubes, severe- ly burning the stoker. Fortunatley, this was the only person injured

The fact is that the engines on this line are very old, and also too few, for the work. They have to be kept continually running, and if they require any repairs, which they often do, these must be done in all haste, in the best possible manner, so as not to stop the traffic. Unless some new locomotives are sent here at once, we may probably have a complete stoppage, in spite of ther exertions and activity of the staff here.

The weather here is of course a bit hot, but bearable, nothing to be compared to the heat of last year. NAturally Luxor is quite deserted now, and the residents' only recreation is to await the Cairo express with letters and papers, and even this hardly ever arrives in time.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON MARKET
div.p: Messrs. Collinge Brothers cable as follows:- Liverpool 26th May. - Expect coming Bureau acreage less than expected; think we shall be higher before Bureau. Expect Prince's estimate Monday very bullish.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO
div.p: The Castellani company gave Rigoletto on Thursday in a most satisfactory manner. We must especially praise the tenor, Signor Bat- tian, who used all the numerous opportunities a tenor has in Rigoletto to the greatest ad- vantage. So far as action an manner went his voice, as a voice, is delightful, sweet and strong, indeed very far superior to what is usually held to pass for tenor in Cairo. Gilda (Siga. di Spada) had much charm, and most delicate and flexible intonation Rigoletto himself was disappointing: his notes are too much drawn out with an excessive vibrato which became annoying at times: besides, he was far too sorrow- ful for Rigoletto, who should be sardonic and grim at his moments, and not always and soley given over to gried. The chorus and orchestra were good, but the former need keep ing together, and the latter are too loud at times.

It is a great gain to have so satisfactory a company at this dull season; also the theartre, large and spacious and comfortable, is a great improvement on the ex-Verdiorother such, The programme promises well, and we are to have a large selection of pieces (especially Verdi) which are seldom heard out of Italy. Best of all, by not the Puccini-Mascagni sweet-stuff has been 'worked off,' and almost all to come in more or less novelty.

div.head: DELTA-HOOKER FUSION
div.p: ARRANGEMENT COMPLETED

We have been authorized to state that an arragement has been completed between the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Com- pany, Limited, and the Egyptian Land and General Trust Company, Limited, whereby the former company acquires the assets of the latter in consideration of an exchange of one Delta Land share for every six General Trust shares.

In our opinion the above arrangement should prove favourable to both parties to it. We have reason to belive that its conclusion has removed all causes of friction between the manager, Mr. J. W. Williamson, and the London board of the Delta Land and Invest- ment Company, on the local board of which Mr. Williamson will remain.

div.head: STOCK EXCHANGE CASE
div.p: This morning the case of Thrasybule Anas- tassion v. Goussio and comapny came on for hearing before the Commercial Court of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunals. The plaintiff, who was represented by Mr. Gooding, claims a commission of £175 on some Bourse transac- tions. The case was called and Maltre Lom- bardo, defendant's counsel, asked for an adjournment, which was granted. The case came on in 1904, when there were no less than seven adjournments. The attention of the Court was called to this fact and an objection raised, which was over-ruled.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: Messrs. George Nungovich Bey, Eugene Nahman, Guido Maroni, Alfonso Campos, Auguste Landauer, Roberto Levi, and Elie Piha Bey have formed themselves into a preli- minary association with the object of applying to the Egyptian Government for a firman authorisisng the constitution of a limited liability company (societe anonyme) the name of which will be the Societe Generale d'Electricite et de Mecanique, and which will be established at Alexandria. The objects of the company are the exploitation of every application of elec- trical and mechanical energy, the purchase and sale, under any form, of all material and machinery, any enterprise or operations con- nected therewith, and generally any commercial, indistrial, or other operation necessary to the conduct of the comany's business. The capital of the company will be £50,000, divided into 12,500 shares of £4 each. These chares have been subscribed by the promoters in the following proportions: - Nungovich Bey, 7,500; Eguene Nahman, 1,500; G. Maroni, 1,000; Alfred Campos, 750; A. Landauer, 500; Elie Piha Bey, 1,000; Roberto Levi, 250. There are also 4,500 founders' chares, which will be distributed among the above. Messrs. Eugene Nahman and Guido Maroni have agreed to hold themselves at the disposal of the company for the management of its affairs for a period of five years, and to secure for the company the services of the engineer, M. Roberto Levi, as assistant amager for the same period.

div.head: WADY RAYAN
div.p: Washington, April 26. Vice-President Fairbanks yesturday present- ed to the Senate a petition from Cope White- house asking for an investigation of his claim against the Egyptian Government for arid lands. The petition was referred to the Com- mittee on Foreign Relations.

div.head: THE BAHR-EL GHAZAL PROVINCE.
div.p: The "London Gazette" contains a despatch from Lord Cromer dated August 27, 1905, forwarding reports from the Sirdar, Major- General Sir R. Wingate, on the operations against the Nyam-Nyam tribes in the Southern Bahr-el-Ghazal Procince during the early part of that year. The Sirdar, after referring warmly to ther services of the late Major Boulnois, in command of the force, who died from the effects of dysentery last May at Mvolo and Lieutenant J.L. Fell (late R.N.), who succumbed to black water fever, specially mention the following officers: - Major Car- ter, who effected the capture of Yambio; Major H. A. Bray (Royal Army Medical Corps), principal medical officer of the force; Captain H. Gordon (Leicester Regiment). commanding 10th Sudanese Battalion; Captain A. J. B. Percival, D.S.O. (Northumberland Fusiliers), commanding Mounted Infantry; Captain A.B. Bethell (Royal Artillery); Captain R.I. Rawson (Northumberland Fusiliers), who acted as staff officer to the lat Major Boulnois; Captain S.K. Flint (Royal Fusiliers), who was in charge of the transport. As already announced, Captains Sutherland and Flint are promoted to the rank of major, while it is notified that Major Boulnois would have been recom- mended to his Majesty for reward had he lived.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ekkerman S.S. Sardina sailed hence on Saturday evening for Liverpool via Malta with passengers and general cargo, including 458 bales of cotton.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo from Marseilles passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here tomorrow.
The Papayanni line Alsatian left Malta on the 27th inst and is expected to arrive here on Thursday next.
The S.S. Indian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on Sunday and is due at Alexandria, cia Tunis and Malta, on or about June 12.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: SECOND SUMMER MEETING
SECOND DAY'S RACING

Though the closing day's card of the A.S.C. Second Summer Meeting did not promise to furnish anything out of the common, the pro- ceedings were not without a good deal of interest. The weather was much pleasanter than on the preceding day, in fact, ideal conditions prevailed, and the attendance of the public wasa decided improvement on Thurs- dya, while the racing was of the best de- scription. The May Selling Race was generally conceded to Mashkour, judging by his form, and it is pretty certain that had he been asled sooner, he would have taken the race from Venicius, who won pretty comfortably with Challoner on. Aurelius, in the Centenary Handicap, fully justified the good opinion we formed of him on the previous day. On his performance of that day he was freely backed, though Brown Boy and Bonus received a good deal of support at the Pari Mutuel. There is, however, scarcely a better horse in the country than Aurelius, and he is certianly a valuable acquisition to his owner. Jenkins handled him with admirable judgement and allowed him to run his own race, never bustling him a bit. Prince Omar Toussoun aslo had a good run for his money with Quick Returns, who is a promising mare and should yet distinguish herself. Ragueh's win in the Montaza Plate was a decided sur- prise to most backers, although with the wight he carried it is eveident he was simply thrown in. El Tahawi was regarded as a hopeless quantitiy after his performance on Thursday, and Sweetie started hot favourite. He however ran a perfect pig, as the mo- ment he was caught up he gave way and refused to be urged. El Tahawi certainly dealt more kindly with Bonser than with his own jockey, Stillwell, on Thursday, but this only proves that he is a horse of moods, as there could be no doubt about his form. Quita the greatest surprise of the card was Lehek's victory in the Owners' Handicap, which was unlooked for by backers, or the owners either, as they placed a stable-boy on him. That the pny is one of potentialities, however, is proved by the fact that he com- pletely ran away with the race. In the straight his success was never in doubt, as he fairly out strode his 18 opponenets from the cut- ting. Radium, who looked bright in his coat and altogether very fit when stripped for the race, could never even get on terms with him and finished a rather poor second, although this was partly to be accounted for by the fact that he had the outside number and could never get in the inside. India and Sadik too, who gave a certain amount of promise, failed dismally, the former only being even placed. The May Handicap was remark- able for the performance of that old horse London, who for three successive seasons has not been known to do anthing brilliant. Though hard pressed by Valentino, he won without being called upon for any serious effeort by half-a-length. This improvement in his manners must be highly gratifying to his owner, and the lesson to be deduced is that with care- ful treatment and judious handling, he may yet redeem a reputation which was at the outset a brilliant one. The Pony Stakes was won very easily by Suleik, although, with Jenkins on, his win was harldy to be doubted. Miassar, it is true ran very strong and might have had the race had his jockey kept him in line, but we think he waited too long and allowed Suleik and Kara Aslan to get the better of him. The following is a description of the various events:-

Some delay was caused at the post owing to Sweetie breaking through the tape,but the flag fell to an excellent start, Sweeties, El Tahawi, Vandal, and Ragueh getting away in a line and keeping company in front till coming out of the cutting, when Sweetie and El Tahawi made a race of it, with Ragueh in close attendance, Vandal and Rainbow in their rear. Half way up the straight Sweetie looked all over a winner but could not stay the distance, and Ragueh was sent to the front, winning a fine race by 2 lengths from Sweetie, El Tahawi 3 lengths behind, third. Sweetie was disqualified on weighing out and El Tahwai got second place, with Kara Aalan third. Time: 1.8.
Totalisator paid P.T. 190 on winner, and P.T. 62, 54, and 48 for places.

The big field of 19 runners were all down at the post in excellent time, and the starter has no difficulty in getting them off. Mikado showed the way from Wino Tinto, nimrod, adn Shai- boob, and made the running till passing the mile post, when Lahek was sent to the front, with Radium hard pressing him till entering the cutting, when he drew away from easy fashion and never being challenged won comfortably by 3 lengths; one length separated 2nd and 3rd; the rest of the field were straggling. Time: 2.30.

This order was maintained to the straight, when Tamerlan seemed to tire and London took up the running, followed by Valentino and Chendi, and though hard pressed by Valentino won an excellent race by half a length, Chendi 4 lengths behind, third. Kara Aslan jumped off and made the run- ning to the mile post, where he was caught up by Kawkab. The pair raced together till coming out of the cutting, when Kawab was done with and Suleik, gradually getting on terms with the leader, show ahead and won in the easiest fashion by 4 lengths; a neck divi- ded 2nd and 3rd; the others were nowhere. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: A dinner was given at the New Khedival Hotel on Saturday by H.E> the Governor of Alexandria in honour of Col. Bird, the retiring commanding officer of the 1sr Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers. Besides Col. Bird and Mrs. and Miss Brid, the guests present were Col. Chapman, now in command of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Col. Edwards, commanding the 4th Battalion Worcestershire Regiment, Major Hovel, Capt. Crawley, Col. Hopkinson Bey, the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Mrs. Hokin- son, Chataway Bey, Mr. E.W.P. Foster, C.M.G., Mr. and Mrs. Kingham, Mr. and Mrs. Dickson, Hassan Bey Ibadi, the Governor's son, etc., etc.

Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to El Miralai Stanton Bey, Go- verneor, Khartoum Province; El Miralai Haw- ker Bey, Governor, Red Sea Province; El Kaimakan Lloyd Bey, Senior Inspector, Kor- dofan Province; El Kaimakam O'Sullivan Bey, Senior Inspector, Upper Nile Province; El Bimbashi Drake Ddeputy Assistant adju- tant General, and El Bimbashi Jeffcoat, D.S.O., 10th Sudanese.
The following officers of the 1st Lancashire Fusiliers have been granted leave of absence on private affairs: Majors H.V.F. Benet and F.C.L. Logan and Captains E.Hewlett and E.K. Purnell.
M. Gerassimo, director of the Jerusalem branch of the Credi Luonnais, has been appointed director of the agency of the Natio- nal Bank of Greece at Alexandria.
Mulszim Awal Blattner of the Alexandria City Police, has been promoted to the rank of Yousbashi.

The numerous old boys of the Christian Brothers at alexandria will learn with regret of the death of Brother Oliviero, which occurred last night at the advanced age of 81. Of the 61 years of his religious life the deceased spent over 40 at St. Catherine's College, teaching the junior classes. In this possition he gained the confidence and respect of his superiors and the good-will and esteem of all who knew him. He devoted himself with much zeal and energy to the work confided to his care, nd under his influence boys advanced in the path of virtue and science. He is the last of the group of pioneers who laid the bases of St. Catherine's College, and who did so much in this land for the good education of youth. His mortal re- mains will be laid to rest this afternoon at 4 p.m.

The friends whom Princess Chimay made during her various sojourns in Cario will be interested to hear of her latest adventure. The eccentric Princess has just taken her last Italian husband on a visit to the mother of the gipsy violinist Rigo, in the village of Rakzod. The Princess brought from Paris a tombstone for rigo's father, who is buried there. She confided to her ex-mother-in-law that she was unhappy in her present mariage, and hoped to recover Rigo. On hearing of Rigo;s financial difficulties in America she telegraphed a large sum, but it was declined. After scattering money in the village, the Princess has arrived at Budapest, where she proposes to earn more by exhibing herself as a "living statue."

div.head: UNION ARTISQUE FRANCAISE
div.p: Samedi a eu lieu a l'Union Artistique Fran- caise une soiree intime, artisque et musicale.
Au cours de la representation, nous avons pu nous persuader des reels talents que possede cette societe.

Deux comedies en un acte ont ete don- nees: "Madame a ses Brevets" ou Mme A. Paul, Mile Prinoth et > Hornbostel out remporte un succes tres merite, puis "Les conferences chez Beaubichon" dont l'execution hardie fut tout a la louange de Mile Prinoth, MM. Paul, Tranpani, Levy; une mention spe- ciale est due a M. Christaki, qui possefe un talent et une connaissance de la scene que lui envieraient bien des professionels.

Que'ques intermedes par MM. Lamon, Sacco, Papanti, Achikiam, Levy, Corbo, sont venus partager le spectacle. N'oublions pas M. Aime Paul, le gai tourlourou, dans ses chansonettes militaires. Dans ce genre M. Paul excelle et il n'est point douteux que s'il en eut fait carriere, il eut reussi.

En resume elcellente soiree; nous sommes heureux de presenter nos felicitations a M. Paul, le distingue president, qui par son ama- bilite et son tact n'a pas peu contribue au succes de l'Union Artistique Francaise.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Samefi 26 Mai.
Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres vient d'etre reduit de 3/8 a 3 1/8 pour cent.

Hier, au stock Exchange, le Consolide sn- glasis est reste encore incarie a 89 3/4. L'Uni- fiee a cluture avec 1/4 de hausse a 104 1/4. La National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daira sont demeurees immobiles a leurs cours precedents. La Delta Light a regagne 1/4 de livre a 12 1/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Froncier Egyptian a reactionne de 1 frauc a 772. La Banque d'Athe- nes est reestee inchangee a 151 francs.
Sur notre marche, la reprise que nous a vions prevue et expliquee dans notre circulaire du 23 courant, et qui s'etait dessince des hier matin, s'est vivement accentuee anjourd'hui.
La National Bank a ainsi avance de 26 1/32 a 26 1/4 5.16. L'Agricole a gague 1/16 a 9 7/8. Le Comptoir Financier s'est raffermi a 5 13/16-7/8.
L'action Credit Foncier a progresse a 777 et la part de fondateur a 1020-1030. La Daira a avance a 17 5/16-3/8 et la Delta Light a 12 3/8.
La Nile Land a recile a 14. Les omnibus du Caire ont ete traites a 28.

Dans le groupe de Hotels, grand mouve- ment sure les Nungovich, qui ont ete pousses a 16 3/16 pour clourer a 16 1/8. Les Bahler en forte demande, ont ete egalement l'objet de monbreuses transactions ils ont monte jusqu'a 5 3/8 pour cloturer a 5/16. Les Upper Egypt ont ete cotes a 4 5/16-3/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont progresse a 4 1/16-1/8, et les Hooker ont ete recherches a 1 1/32. On rapporte que la fusion entre ces deux Societes aurait ete signee hier soir sur les bases que nous avons indiquees hier. Le general Hallowes, chariman de la Delta Co., avait ete delegue specialement a cet effect su Caire, ou il se se trouve depuis avant-hier.
Les Estates se sont raffermis a 1 5/8-11/16 et leur part de fondateur est remontee a 10 5/16. Les Oasis ont avance a 1-3/32 et les Surcreries a 21.

En parlant du mouvement qui s'est produit sur les actions de la Nungovich Hotels Co., un journal d'Alexandrie d'hier persiste a l'attri- buer au fait que, malgre les dementis publies au Caire, la fusion entre cette societe et l'Egyp- tial Hotels CO. seriat decidee en principe.

La bonne foi de ce journal a ete assurment surprise, car nous sommes en measure d'affirmes que toutes les rumeurs propagees en Bourse a ce sujet, dans un but aise a deviner, n'ont jamais eu le moindre fondement.

Il saute, d'ailleurs, aux yeux, pour nous ser- vir des expressions memes du journal en ques tion, qu'en presence de la situation floris- sante des Egyptian Hotels et des brillantes perspectives que leur ouvent le developpement projete de leur exploitation, ainsi que la plus- value enorme acquise par leurs terrains de Ghezi- reh, qu;une fusion irait a l'encontre des interet reale des actionnaires de la Societe. Leur titre est appeale en effet, a atteindre rapidement un prix presque doble de cours actuel. Il serait donc naif de leur part de faire beneficier inuti- lement des tiers de cette aubine.
Eu attendant, le dividende qui sera propo- se a l'assemblee generale ordinaire du 21 Juin prochain sere, parait-il de 15%.

On ajoute qu'il est question de la transforma- tion de la Compagnie. La Societe actuelle se- rait dissoute et ses actions remboursees a £5. On la remplacerait par une nouvelle Societe. dont l'emission aurait lieu l'hiver prochain. Il serait donne aux anciens detenteurs le droit de souscrire a 4 actions de la nouvelle Compagnie contre un action des Egyptian Hotels.

L'assemblee generale ordinaries de la Ham- burg and Anglo-American Nile Co. s'est tenne heir, a 5h. 30 p.m., au Continental Hotel au Caire. Les comptes et le bilan de l'exercice 1905- 1906 ont ete approuves. Il a ete decide, con- formement a la proposition du conseil d'admi- nistration, de payer un dividende de 6 1/2 pour cent et de reporter a nouveau la somme de L. E. 1801.36

Dans un de ses derniers numeros, le "Han- delsblad," un des journaux les plus importants d'Amsterdam, publie un article documente sur le "Credit Foncier Hollandais" dont nous avons eu l'occasion de toucher un mot dans notr Circulaire du 23 Avril dernier.

Le "Handlesblad" qui par suite des atttaques dont cette Societe a ete l'objet, s'est livre a une enquete pour sauvagarder le con renom de la finance neerlandaise, fait observer que le Credit Foncier Holandais a bien son siege en Hol- lande, mais qu'il opera au dehors. Son conseil d'administration est compose de deux membres, auxquels on a sdjoint en derier lieu un etranger. Il n'a pas de direction et encore moins de commissarires ou censeurs.

D'apres ses Statuts, le Credit avait pour objet de faire des operation de bauque, d'e- mettre de obligations hypothecaires et aussi des smprunte a primes. En realite, il s'est emplye uniquement a organiser des loteries.

Le "Handelsblad: dmeontre longuement ensuite, a l'aide de chiffres et en se basant sur les prospectus publies, que "l'emprunt a primes: annonce dans les journaux estrangers et remboursable en 77 ans, ne presente nulle- ment les garanties que le public serait en droit d'exiger.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)
Le marche tres ferme a l'ouverture faisait esperer une hausse, malheureusement ce mou- vement ne s'est pas accentue et tout au con- traire, la cluture a ete farble.

L'agricole est stationaire a 9 7/8. La Natio- nal perd 3/16 a 26 1/8. Les Tramways d'Alex- andrie recilen de fr. 50 a 191 1/2. a Daira Sanieh est a 17 3/16 en baisse de 1/8 sre Samedi. La Salt & Soda est cangee a 21/6. L'Oblagation Credit foncier reactionne a 322 fr.

Depuis le 8 mai du present mois, le 30.000 obligations nouvelles de 500 francs 3 1/2%, numeros 400001 a 430000, du Credit Foncier Egyptian sont admises aux negociations de la Bourse de Paris au comptant.
Ces titres sont inscrits a la premiere partie du Bulletin de la Cote sous le meme rubrique que les obligations anciennes 3 1/2 %.
Par suite, le nombre des obligations 3 1/2% de la dite Societe, negociables sur le marche parisien se trouve prote de 400.000 a 430.000.
La Delta Land a eu les honneurs de la jour- nee, en bonne posture au debut elle faiblit et cloture a 4 7/32.
Le Estates sont a 1 11/16 vendeurs.
En somme le marche est indecis et il est difficile etant donne ses variations de s'arreter a une just hypothese.

div.head: NOTRE BAIN DE PIED S.V.P.
div.p: Decidemet la Municipalite se fiche de nous, manquant a ses devoirs primordiaux.

Comment, heir, elle nous a prive de notre petit bain de pied habituel. Les assidus de l'Alhambra, au sortir de ce theatre n;ont pas eu la douce satisfaction de rtremper... leurs chausettes, les dames de maculer leurs robes, les bottines de se retrecir et les corps aux pieds de se dilater. Nous n'avons pas eu le spectacle, si poetique pourtant, de la reflection des becs de gaz dans les ondes que las municiplaite de- verse a grands flots tout le long de la Rue Cherif.
Il y a la une incurie blamable et il faut esperer que nos gouvernants, toujours, si prompts a satisfaire a toutes nos justes re- vendications, veilleront a ce que ce fait ne se reproduise.

div.head: Supplement Commerical et Financier De "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Einancier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs; les der- nieres statiques justqu'a la veille de sa publi- cation: des tableaux de fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpoot Cotton Association, etc. etc.
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les fairs de poste; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. deport en sus.
Pour de plus amples informations s'adresser au directeur del' "Egyptian Gazette".

div.head: Alexandrian general Produce Association
div.p: SECTION COTONNIERE
QUESTIONNAIRE DE MAI 1906.
(Piere de repondre avant le 4 Juin en vous serrant de la langue que vous preferez.)
1.- Avez vous quelque chose a ajouter a vos informations precedenes, au sujet de l'etendue terres semes en coton?
2.- La temeperature, pendant le mois de Mai, atelle ete favorable ou defavorable aux jeunes cotonniers?
3.- Les jeunes cotonniers sont-ils eu bou etat, ou ont-ils ete contraries par quelque circonstance? (Et laquelle)
4.- remarquez-vaus de retard dans les cultures? sont-elles plus avancees ou plus retardees que l'annee passee?
5.- Depuis quand le reensemencement est- il termine dans votre district?
6.- L'eau pour les irrigations est-elle abon- dante? ou est-elle seulement suffisante? ou bien est-elle insufficante?
7.- Les vers ont-ils apparu dans votre district? et ont-ils fait des degats au Coton- niers?
Pour le Comite Le President C. de TSCHUDI.

div.head: The Nile Cold Storage Company, Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Nile Cold Storage Comapny, Limited, will be held at the offices of the Cairo Water Comapny, Sharia Boulac, Cairo, Egypt, on Wednesday, the 6th day of June 1906, at five o'clock in the afternoon, when the subjoined Resolutions, which were passes at and Extraordinary General Meeting held on Saturday, the 19th day of May, 1906, will be submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions.
RESOLUTIONS.

1. That the Directors be hereby authorized to take the necessary legal steps to reduce the Captial of the Company from £50,00 to £40,000 sterling, reducing each fully paid Ordinary Share from 20/- to 16/- fully paid, and reducing each fully paid Deferred Share from 1/- to 9 2/5d. (or some approximate sum) fully paid: and that the Memorandum and Articles of association of the Company be altered accordingly.

2. That the Directors be hereby authorised to effect an agreement as between the Company and the Holders of the Deferred Shares, whereby the latter shall have the right to thirty-five per per cent of the surplus profits after payment out of such profits of eight per cent per annum on the Ordinary shares in place of one-half thereof as provided in clause one of Article 5 of the Articles of Assocaition of the Company, the right to forty per cent of the resurve fund accumul- ated out of such surplus profits in place of one-half thereof as provided in clause two of the same Article, and the right to forty per cent of the surplus assets in place of one- half thereof as provided in clause three of the same Article: and that Article 5 of the Articles of Association of the Comapny be altered accordingly namely:

that the world "half" afters the words "the right to" in the sixtth line of the Article five be struck out and the words "thirty- five per cent of" be subsituted therefore: and that the word "one-half" be similary struck out of the sixteenth and twenty third lines of the same Article and the words "forty per cent" subsituted therefor in each instance.
HOLDERS of SHARE WARRANTS to the BEARER are requested to deposit same with either of the following Banks, viz:-
The National Bank of Egypt.
The Bank of Egypt.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank.
The Imperial Ottoman Bank.
The Credit Lyonnais.
or at the Offices of the Comapny either in London or Cairo at least three days beofre the date of the Meeting.
The recipt for shares depositied must be produced at the Meeting.
Dated this 26th day of May, 1906. By the order of the Board. W.H. PERKINS. Secretary in Egypt. 28002-2-1

div.head: Societe Commercial d'Egypte
div.p: essieurs les actionnaries de la Societe Commerciale d'Egypte sont prevenus ques, con- tormement a l'art. 20 des Statuts de la Societe une assemblee generale ordinarie aura lieu le 30 Juiin 1906, a 4 h. de relevee, au siege de la Societe a Alexandrie.
ORDRE DU JOUR:
1.-Rapport du Conseil d'Administration sur la situation des affaires de la Societe.
2.-Rapport de Messieurs les Censeurs.
3.-Approbation des comptes de fixation du dividende.
4.-Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'e- xercise 1906 1907 et fixation de leur in- demuite annuelle.
5.-Renouvellement par tiers di Conseil d'Ad- ministration.
6.-Propositions diverses.
Nota: Conformement a l'art. 37 des Statuts, tout porteur de 5 actions a droit d'assister a l'assemblee generale ordinarie.
Les actions doivant etre deposees au Siege de la Societe, quinze jours au moins avant l'assemblee generale, c'est a-dire, au plus tard le 15 Juin 1906 (Art. 28 des Statuts).
Le Presisdent du Consiel d'Administration. M. Sinadino.
Alexandrie, le 28 Mai 1906. 28007-3-1
